header.title: TARO of the FOUR WORLDS
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Qabalah, Tarot, Hermeticism

central_thesis: Steve Nichols presents a radical reconstruction of the Tarot, positing its ancient origins in Egyptian and classical Hermetic traditions, rather than medieval European sources. The central thesis is to re-establish a 'TARO of the Four Worlds' as a system of 88 cards, derived from classical mythological iconography (Vincenzo Cartari's *Le Imagini degli Dei degli Antichi*) and interpreted through esoteric texts (Richard Linche's *The Fountaine of Ancient Literature*). These 88 cards are systematically mapped to the 88 'Netibuth' (expanded paths) of the Qabalistic Tree of Life, across its Four Worlds (Atziluth, Briah, Yetzirah, Assiah), offering a sophisticated framework for divination, magical operation, and profound psychological insight.

structure_content.chapter_title: History of the Taro of Four Worlds
structure_content.summary: This foundational chapter asserts the 'TARO of the Four Worlds' as part of an ancient 'Bible of Thoth,' with roots in Egyptian religion. It introduces Richard Linche (1599) and Vincenzo Cartari (c. 1500) as key textual and iconographic sources, respectively. Linche's philosophy of images as 'memorious trophies' of divine Ideas provides the metaphysical justification for using classical mythological figures as esoteric symbols, linking them to a pre-Golden Dawn understanding of Tarot and Qabalah. The chapter contextualizes the work by noting Eliphas Levi's contributions while stating the aim to provide a 'new and further analysis' by attributing icons to the 88 Netibuth.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Isis Tablet or Mensa Isiaca
structure_content.summary: This chapter delves into the Mensa Isiaca, an ancient Egyptian-Roman bronze tablet, as a central symbolic and structural key to the entire 'TARO of the Four Worlds' system. Nichols meticulously analyzes its iconography, correlating its numerous figures and divisions with Qabalistic, Hermetic, and Ptolemaic cosmological principles. It is presented as a visual encoding of the '22 Netibuth or Paths' of the Tree of Life, further subdivided to accommodate the 88 paths across the Four Worlds. The Tablet is shown to embody the 'triple arrangement of the constitution of the world into Archetypal, Intellectual and Sensible,' providing a framework for understanding the interplay of divine powers and their manifestation in reality.

Each of the 88 core chapters introduces a specific card, featuring a unique mythological image, a thematic keyword, and a precise Qabalistic assignment: 'DIVINATION: [Traditional Tarot Arcana], [Qabalistic World]'. This systematic mapping is the operative heart of the system. For instance, '1 Threshold' is assigned to 'The Fool, Atziluth,' representing pure potential; '2 Time' to 'Death, Assiah,' symbolizing temporal cycles; and '15 Lunar' to 'The Moon, Atziluth,' exploring lunar archetypes. Importantly, the same traditional Tarot Arcana (e.g., 'The Moon' or 'The Magician') appear multiple times, each embodied by a different mythological image and assigned to a different Qabalistic World, providing nuanced layers of meaning and operative context (e.g., '15 Lunar' (Moon, Atziluth), '17 The Tides' (Moon, Yetzirah), '52 Night' (Moon, Assiah)). The extensive accompanying text for each card, drawn from Linche and other classical sources, functions as a grimoire of divine attributes and their operative implications within the specified World.

This concluding section offers practical guidance for using the 'TARO of the Four Worlds'. It suggests divinatory spreads, including a linear 'unfolding narrative' (past-present-future) or a 'compass' arrangement (four or eight points). A more advanced method involves placing the cards on an expanded Tree of Life glyph, utilizing the connections between Sephiroth and Qabalistic Worlds for deeper understanding. The text also encourages 'skrying aid' through 'Enochian Chess boards,' hinting at its integration with more complex magical systems. This section underscores the operative nature of the deck beyond mere divination.

key_concepts.definition: A unique esoteric Tarot system comprising 88 cards, each based on a specific image from Vincenzo Cartari's *Le Imagini degli Dei degli Antichi* (Images of the Gods of the Ancients). These images are interpreted through Richard Linche's *The Fountaine of Ancient Literature* and mapped to the 88 'Netibuth' (expanded paths) of the Qabalistic Tree of Life, spread across its Four Worlds (Atziluth, Briah, Yetzirah, Assiah).

A fundamental Qabalistic concept referring to four distinct planes of existence and manifestation: Atziluth (Archetypal/Emanation, divine Will), Briah (Creative, pure intellect), Yetzirah (Formative, emotions and astral forms), and Assiah (Material/Action, physical manifestation). In this system, each card operates within the specific energetic and conceptual framework of its assigned World.

An expansion of the traditional 22 Paths of the Tree of Life. In this system, each of the 22 archetypal paths is considered as manifesting uniquely across the Four Worlds, resulting in 88 distinct 'paths' or energetic currents. Each of the 88 cards embodies one of these specific path-world combinations, providing a highly granular and layered approach to understanding esoteric forces.

An ancient Egyptian-Roman bronze tablet serving as a critical symbolic and structural blueprint for the 'TARO of the Four Worlds'. Nichols argues it contains an encoded cosmological map, embodying the 'triple arrangement of the constitution of the world' and providing a framework for the Qabalistic 22 (and implicitly 88) Netibuth and the Four Worlds. Its complex iconography is interpreted as a direct link to the esoteric roots of the Tarot.

key_concepts.term: Richard Linche's *The Fountaine of Ancient Literature*
key_concepts.definition: A 1599 text providing detailed interpretations of classical deities and mythological scenes. In this Tarot system, Linche's work is the primary interpretive lens through which the visual symbolism of Cartari's images is understood, informing their divinatory meanings and magical applications within the Qabalistic framework. The book argues that Linche's text provides the 'operative significance' of the archetypes.

key_concepts.term: Vincenzo Cartari's *Le Imagini degli Dei degli Antichi*
key_concepts.definition: A 16th-century work that is the direct source for the images used in the 'TARO of the Four Worlds'. These engravings of classical gods and mythological scenes form the visual basis for the 88 cards, connecting the system directly to Renaissance Hermetic and classical scholarship on ancient religion and magic.

practical_system.description: The 'TARO of the Four Worlds' functions as a multi-layered divinatory and magical system. Its core mechanism involves a deck of 88 cards, each representing a distinct mythological archetype (from Cartari) interpreted with specific esoteric meanings (from Linche), and precisely assigned to one of the 88 Netibuth across the Qabalistic Four Worlds. This framework allows for highly specific readings and operations by invoking the precise manifestation of an archetype within a given energetic plane.
tools: The 88-card 'TARO of the Four Worlds' deck (essential)
Knowledge of the Qabalistic Tree of Life and the Four Worlds
Interpretive texts like Richard Linche's *The Fountaine of Ancient Literature* and Vincenzo Cartari's *Le Imagini degli Dei degli Antichi* (for deeper understanding)
Optional: Enochian Chessboards (for advanced 'skrying aid' and integration with other systems)
Optional: A personal journal for recording insights and experiences
rituals: Targeted Invocation: By selecting a card (e.g., '10 The Strength, Atziluth') that embodies the desired quality in a specific World, the practitioner can align with or draw upon that archetypal force.

Meditative Scrying: Contemplating the image and its associated mythological lore, particularly within the context of its assigned World, would facilitate deep meditative states and direct experience of the archetype.
Pathworking: The explicit mapping to the 88 Netibuth suggests a system for advanced Qabalistic pathworking, exploring specific energetic currents across the Tree of Life.
Ceremonial Alignment: The extensive classical and philosophical interpretations serve as a 'grimoire' of divine attributes, enabling the construction of personalized invocations and ritual actions.

relevant_quotes.text: "By representing their Ideas by statues or Pictures, and so by that means keeping them as it were alive by the memorious trophies of their never-dying worthiness, whereby their succeeding posterity might evidently receive what respective regard was had and canonised of those."
"This strange taro is part of the 'Bible of Thoth,' tracing their roots (for the most part) back to ancient Egyptian religion and the mists of time."
"The eighty-eight images of this book were already ancient when Linche wrote the above words."
"I have attributed icons to the 88 Netibuth of the four Worlds, and indicated their traditional titles based on the Qabalistic tree of 22 Netibuth or Paths."
"The Tablet embodies the triple arrangement of the constitution of the world into Archetypal, Intellectual and Sensible; the Paternal mind as a centre gives motion and animation to all things."

"Another method of use is to place the taro on the expanded Tree of Life glyph of the Four Worlds. The paths and connections between Sephiroth, and also between Qabalistic Worlds, can assist our understanding as we follow them in sequence."
"Yet another divinatory and skrying aid is to place the cards on appropriate squares amongst the four Enochian Chess boards, perhaps on stands."

critical_analysis.relevance: This book offers a highly significant contribution to esoteric studies by providing a meticulously researched and reconstructed Tarot system that diverges from the popular Golden Dawn and French esoteric models. Its emphasis on classical iconography (Cartari) and interpretive depth (Linche) grounds the Tarot in a rich pre-modern Hermetic and Neoplatonic philosophical tradition, directly linking it to Egyptian and Roman mysteries via the Isis Tablet. The 88 Netibuth mapping provides a unique Qabalistic framework, adding unprecedented layers of nuance to traditional Tarot archetypes by expressing them across the Four Worlds. This work is crucial for understanding alternative historical lineages and operative methods within Tarot magic and Qabalah.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of advanced practitioners and academic researchers of Western Esotericism, Qabalah, Hermeticism, and historical Tarot. Individuals with a solid foundation in the Tree of Life and classical mythology will find it most valuable. It is an ideal resource for magicians seeking to reconstruct or integrate pre-Golden Dawn magical systems, for those interested in the 'operative' side of Tarot, and for scholars exploring the evolution of esoteric thought. It is not suitable for beginners due to its dense intellectual and philosophical demands.
